content.webTitle: A good day for the kids

fields.headline: A good day for the kids
fields.bodyText: By chance, the winners of the 14th annual Guardian Charity Awards all worked with children, young people and their families. It made for a moving ceremony at the Tate Modern in London, where the awards were presented by Dame Suzi Leather, Charity Commission chair. The awards, for small and medium-sized charities, are intended to recognise innovative practice that fills a gap in social welfare provision. Paying tribute to the distinctive role of smaller charities, Leather said: "Their creativity, independence, their tenacity in pursuing their vision and championing their causes is truly impressive." Sponsored by NatWest and the Royal Bank of Scotland, the awards offer each of the five winners a prize of £6,000, plus a new PC provided by Smartchange.org, which promotes employee giving to charities. This year's winners are: · 1Voice, which brings together children and young people without speech, most of whom use communication technology. · Motorvations, which works with young people excluded from formal education. · Mosac, which helps families of children who have suffered sexual abuse. · KPC Youth, a community project engaging young people and keeping them away from drugs and crime. · Nacoa, the National Association of Children of Alcoholics, which supports youngsters living with parents with alcohol problems. Leather urged smaller charities not to feel pressured into playing down their campaigning role. She told the winners: "Please be in no doubt at all that speaking out on the causes you represent is a key part of your charitable activity." This year's judges were: Jane Asher, president of the National Autistic Society, Lady Howarth, former chief executive of ChildLine, Stuart Etherington, chief executive of the National Council for Voluntary Organisations, Tracey Betts, of NatWest/RBS, Vinay Khosla, of Smartchange.org, and David Brindle, public services editor of the Guardian.
